title: About
text:
class Me:
    def __init__(self):
        self.name = "Yingqi Wang"
        self.born_year = "2000" 
        self.MBTI = "ESTP" 😎
        self.hometown = "Hubei, China" 🇨🇳
        self.location = "Baltimore, MD, US 🇺🇸
        self.pet = "cat" 🐱
I am Yingqi Wang, and I am originally from Hubei,China. Now I am a second-year MHS student in General Epidemiology Methods(GEM) track under the Department of Epidemiology. My research intersts mainly focus on Pharmacoepidemiology and neurodegenerative disease, to be more specific, using real-world data to analyse the effectiveness and saftey of medications for Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease.

title: About
text:
class Me:
    def __init__(self):
        self.name = "Yingqi Wang"
        self.born_year = "2000" 
        self.MBTI = "ESTP" 😎
        self.hometown = "Hubei, China" 🇨🇳
        self.location = "Baltimore, MD, US 🇺🇸
        self.pet = "cat" 🐱
I am Yingqi Wang, and I am originally from Hubei,China. Now I am a second-year MHS student in General Epidemiology Methods(GEM) track under the Department of Epidemiology. My research intersts mainly focus on Pharmacoepidemiology and neurodegenerative disease, to be more specific, using real-world data to analyse the effectiveness and saftey of medications for Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease.

title: About
text:
Education 🎓

 Johns Hopkins University (JHU) | Baltimore, MD, US
 MHS in Epidemiology | 2023 - 2025
 Nanjing Agricultural University (NJAU) | Jiangsu, China
 B.S. in Animal Science | 2018 - 2022

title: About
text:
Experience 💼

 Departments of Neurology, School of Medicine, JHU  | Baltimore, MD, US
 Reasearch Assistant |  04/2024 - present 
Assisted in a retrospective cohort study evaluating the association between the use of amiloride and the risk of Parkinson’s disease.
Conducted data extraction and cleaning from large-scale health claims databases (CMS data) to identify eligible patients and outcomes.
Performed statistical analyses, including propensity score weighting and time-to-event analysis, using SAS.

 Data Operations Department, SCW Medicath Ltd.  | Guangdong, China
 Data Analyst Assistant |  10/2022 - 12/2022

Extracted and analyzed dealer sales data through SQL; integrated customer resources according to sales, sales volume, growth rate and repurchase rate, etc., and used R for data visualization.
Collected daily data generated by different departments, integrated the data through Excel, quantified the indicators, established the KPI performance assessment system, and conducted data visualization on the progress of the departments’ monthly indicators.

title: About
text:
Activities 🎡

 Department of Extracurricular Activities, College Students Art Troupe, NJAU  | Jiangsu, China
 Vice Minister  | 09/2018 - 08/2020
Organized and coordinated three large-scale student performances, including drama, dance, and vocal recitals, engaging over 200 participants. Collaborated with faculty to develop performance themes, secure resources, and manage logistics for rehearsal spaces, costumes, and instruments.
 Students for the International Society for Pharmacoepidemiology (SISPE), JHU  | Baltimore, MD, US
 Journal Club Coordinator  | 09/2024 - present

Selected and organized relevant journal articles for review, working closely with students and faculty. Facilitated discussions on study design, methodology, and clinical implications to enhance participants’ critical appraisal and presentation skills.

title: Example Analysis
text:
This analysis investigates the beneficiary cost burden associated with Top 20 high-use drugs in Medicare Part D in 2022, as well as spending trends from 2018 to 2022. The data for this analysis comes from Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (2024).


Prescription drug spending constitutes a significant portion of healthcare costs, particularly within the Medicare Part D program, which provides prescription drug coverage to millions of beneficiaries in the United States. In recent years, rising expenditures on specialty drugs and high-use medications have highlighted the financial burden borne by both the healthcare system and individual beneficiaries. Understanding the cost distribution and trends among these high-use drugs is critical for developing strategies to enhance affordability and sustainability in prescription drug coverage(Hernandez, Good, and Gellad 2020).




 Research Question : “What is the beneficiary cost burden for Top 20 high-use drugs in Medicare Part D in 2022, and how has spending on these drugs changed from 2018 to 2022?”
 Audience : Healthcare policymakers, public health researchers, and Medicare program administrators concerned with cost burdens and the rising expenses of frequently prescribed drugs.






Medicare Part D Drugs






 Data Source : Medicare Part D Spending by Drug dataset.
 Data Dictionary : Medicare Part D Spending by Drug Data Dictionary





Image 1: Medicare part D Drug Tiers








Note



Medicare Part D data includes a series of datasets that provide information on prescription drugs prescribed by individual physicians and other healthcare professionals and paid for under the Medicare Part D Prescription Drug program. These datasets contain information on total number of prescriptions dispensed, and the total drug cost by National Provider Identifier (NPI), prescription drug, and geography(Jung C 2019).





To explore trends, I focused on high-use drugs and calculated key metrics:

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dplyr)

data <- read_csv("MedicarePartD.csv")

Rows: 13889 Columns: 46
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (3): Brnd_Name, Gnrc_Name, Mftr_Name
dbl (43): Tot_Mftr, Tot_Spndng_2018, Tot_Dsg_Unts_2018, Tot_Clms_2018, Tot_B...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

filtered_data <- data %>%
  filter(Mftr_Name == "Overall") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2018) & 
         !is.na(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2019) & 
         !is.na(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2020) & 
         !is.na(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2021) & 
         !is.na(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022))

top20_drugs <- filtered_data %>%
  arrange(desc(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 20)

top20_drugs

# A tibble: 20 × 46
   Brnd_Name Gnrc_Name      Tot_Mftr Mftr_Name Tot_Spndng_2018 Tot_Dsg_Unts_2018
   <chr>     <chr>             <dbl> <chr>               <dbl>             <dbl>
 1 Strensiq  Asfotase Alfa         1 Overall         69696199.             11427
 2 Myalept   Metreleptin           1 Overall         11357421.              2533
 3 Vimizim   Elosulfase Al…        1 Overall         13906366.             60485
 4 Ravicti   Glycerol Phen…        1 Overall         40112522.            214475
 5 Cinryze   C1 Esterase I…        1 Overall         97049541.             33118
 6 Procysbi  Cysteamine Bi…        1 Overall         21177206.            218436
 7 Lumizyme  Alglucosidase…        1 Overall         28551424.             38056
 8 Kalbitor  Ecallantide           1 Overall         36874747.              7684
 9 Juxtapid  Lomitapide Me…        1 Overall          9140587.              6797
10 Berinert  C1 Esterase I…        1 Overall         36184189.             12473
11 Actimmune Interferon Ga…        1 Overall         18992802.              2118
12 Ruconest  C1 Esterase I…        1 Overall          5106685.               868
13 Chenodal  Chenodiol             1 Overall         18012010.             36820
14 Soliris   Eculizumab            1 Overall         55437287.            246609
15 Takhzyro  Lanadelumab-F…        2 Overall         12343788.              1096
16 Haegarda  C1 Esterase I…        1 Overall         61885500.             24973
17 Cerezyme  Imiglucerase          1 Overall         12661395.              7933
18 Acthar    Corticotropin         1 Overall        724638119.             90830
19 Fabrazyme Agalsidase Be…        1 Overall         23846850.             12515
20 Vpriv     Velaglucerase…        1 Overall          8476836.              8301
# ℹ 40 more variables: Tot_Clms_2018 <dbl>, Tot_Benes_2018 <dbl>,
#   Avg_Spnd_Per_Dsg_Unt_Wghtd_2018 <dbl>, Avg_Spnd_Per_Clm_2018 <dbl>,
#   Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2018 <dbl>, Outlier_Flag_2018 <dbl>,
#   Tot_Spndng_2019 <dbl>, Tot_Dsg_Unts_2019 <dbl>, Tot_Clms_2019 <dbl>,
#   Tot_Benes_2019 <dbl>, Avg_Spnd_Per_Dsg_Unt_Wghtd_2019 <dbl>,
#   Avg_Spnd_Per_Clm_2019 <dbl>, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2019 <dbl>,
#   Outlier_Flag_2019 <dbl>, Tot_Spndng_2020 <dbl>, Tot_Dsg_Unts_2020 <dbl>, …






ggplot(top20_drugs, aes(x = reorder(Brnd_Name, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022), y = Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022))  +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "#96c5e6", width = 0.7) + 
  geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022)), 
            hjust = -0.2, color = "#333333", size = 3) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 20 High-Use Drugs by Spending per Beneficiary in 2022",
       subtitle = "Medicare Part D Analysis",
       x = "Drug Name",
       y = "Average Spending per Beneficiary ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", hjust = 0.3, color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 15, face = "italic", hjust = 0.4, color = "#6B6B6B"), 
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    axis.title = element_text(size = 15, color = "#333333"), 
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5), 
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 12, color = "#6B6B6B", hjust = 0) 
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)









ggplot(top20_drugs, aes(x = reorder(Brnd_Name, Tot_Spndng_2022), y = Tot_Spndng_2022)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#66cccc", width = 0.7) + 
  geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(Tot_Spndng_2022)), 
            hjust = -0.2, color = "#333333", size = 3) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 20 High-Use Drugs by Total Spending in 2022",
       subtitle = "Medicare Part D Analysis",
       x = "Drug Name",
       y = "Total Spending ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", hjust = 0.3, color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 15, face = "italic", hjust = 0.4, color = "#6B6B6B"), 
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    axis.title = element_text(size = 15, color = "#333333"), 
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5), 
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 12, color = "#6B6B6B", hjust = 0) 
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)









trend_data <- top20_drugs %>%
  select(Brnd_Name, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2018, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2019, 
         Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2020, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2021, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_"),
               names_to = "Year",
               names_prefix = "Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_",
               values_to = "Average_Spending") %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year),
         Brnd_Name = factor(Brnd_Name, levels = top20_drugs$Brnd_Name))  
ggplot(trend_data, aes(x = Year, y = Average_Spending, color = Brnd_Name)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  facet_wrap(~ Brnd_Name, scales = "free_y") + 
  labs(title = "Spending Trends for Top 20 High-Use Drugs (2018–2022)",
       subtitle = "A comparison of average spending per beneficiary over time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Average Spending per Beneficiary ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +  
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",  
    plot.title = element_text(size = 24, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 18, face = "italic", hjust = 0.5, color = "#6B6B6B"),  
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 15, color = "#666666", hjust = 0), 
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold", angle = 45, hjust = 1),  
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()  
  ) +
  scale_color_viridis_d()









trend_total_spending <- top20_drugs %>%
  select(Brnd_Name, Tot_Spndng_2018, Tot_Spndng_2019, 
         Tot_Spndng_2020, Tot_Spndng_2021, Tot_Spndng_2022) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Tot_Spndng_"),
               names_to = "Year",
               names_prefix = "Tot_Spndng_",
               values_to = "Total_Spending") %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year),
         Brnd_Name = factor(Brnd_Name, levels = top20_drugs$Brnd_Name))


ggplot(trend_total_spending, aes(x = Year, y = Total_Spending, color = Brnd_Name)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  facet_wrap(~ Brnd_Name, scales = "free_y") +  
  labs(title = "Total Spending Trends for Top 20 High-Use Drugs (2018–2022)",
       subtitle = "Annual total spending for each top drug by 2022 spending",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Spending ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",  
    plot.title = element_text(size = 24, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 18, face = "italic", hjust = 0.5, color = "#6B6B6B"),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 15, color = "#666666", hjust = 0),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold", angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),
    strip.text = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"), 
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  scale_color_viridis_d() 














Important



In the spending trend plots, each drug has its own y-axis range to better visualize its individual changes over time. This means that the y-axis scales are not uniform, and we should avoid making direct horizontal comparisons between drugs. Instead, focus on the trends within each drug.





This analysis highlights the beneficiary cost burden and spending trends for the top 20 high-use drugs in Medicare Part D. In 2022, Strensiq, Myalept, and Vimizim emerged as the drugs with the highest average spending per beneficiary, reflecting their significant cost implications for individual patients. On the other hand, Acthar, Soliris, and Strensiq dominated total spending in 2022, underscoring their broader economic impact on the Medicare program.Spending trends from 2018 to 2022 reveal substantial variability among drugs, with some like Cinryze and Ravicti exhibiting relatively steady costs, while others like Haegarda and Acthar experienced significant fluctuations. These patterns suggest diverse factors influencing drug pricing, such as changes in demand, pricing strategies, or treatment availability.



Functions Used

dplyr
filter(): To subset the data, such as filtering for “Overall” manufacturers and excluding rows with missing values for spending.
arrange(): To sort the data by descending order of spending.
slice_head(): To select the top 20 drugs based on spending.
mutate(): To create new variables such as Year for trend analysis.
select(): To subset specific columns for trend analysis.

tidyr
pivot_longer(): To transform spending data from wide to long format for trend visualization.

ggplot2
geom_bar(): To create bar plots for spending per beneficiary and total spending.
geom_col(): As an alternative for bar charts with geom_bar().
geom_line(): To create line plots for spending trends over time.
geom_text(): To annotate bar plots with spending values.
facet_wrap(): To create faceted plots for trends, separating each drug into its own panel.
labs(): To add titles, subtitles, captions, and axis labels.
scale_color_viridis_d(): To assign distinctive colors for trend lines in faceted plots.
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma): To format y-axis values for better readability.
theme(): To customize the overall appearance of plots, such as adjusting text sizes, colors, and gridlines.

title: Example Analysis

In recent years, rising expenditures on specialty drugs and high-use medications have highlighted the financial burden borne by both the healthcare system and individual beneficiaries. Understanding the cost distribution and trends among these high-use drugs is critical for developing strategies to enhance affordability and sustainability in prescription drug coverage(Hernandez, Good, and Gellad 2020).

Medicare Part D Drugs

text:

title: Example Analysis
text:
ggplot(top20_drugs, aes(x = reorder(Brnd_Name, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022), y = Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022))  +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "#96c5e6", width = 0.7) + 
  geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022)), 
            hjust = -0.2, color = "#333333", size = 3) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 20 High-Use Drugs by Spending per Beneficiary in 2022",
       subtitle = "Medicare Part D Analysis",
       x = "Drug Name",
       y = "Average Spending per Beneficiary ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", hjust = 0.3, color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 15, face = "italic", hjust = 0.4, color = "#6B6B6B"), 
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    axis.title = element_text(size = 15, color = "#333333"), 
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5), 
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 12, color = "#6B6B6B", hjust = 0) 
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)









ggplot(top20_drugs, aes(x = reorder(Brnd_Name, Tot_Spndng_2022), y = Tot_Spndng_2022)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#66cccc", width = 0.7) + 
  geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(Tot_Spndng_2022)), 
            hjust = -0.2, color = "#333333", size = 3) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 20 High-Use Drugs by Total Spending in 2022",
       subtitle = "Medicare Part D Analysis",
       x = "Drug Name",
       y = "Total Spending ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", hjust = 0.3, color = "#4E4E4E"), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 15, face = "italic", hjust = 0.4, color = "#6B6B6B"), 
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold", color = "#4E4E4E"),

    axis.title = element_text(size = 15, color = "#333333"), 
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
    panel.grid.major.x = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5), 
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 12, color = "#6B6B6B", hjust = 0) 
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)









trend_data <- top20_drugs %>%
  select(Brnd_Name, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2018, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2019, 
         Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2020, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2021, Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_2022) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_"),
               names_to = "Year",
               names_prefix = "Avg_Spnd_Per_Bene_",
               values_to = "Average_Spending") %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year),
         Brnd_Name = factor(Brnd_Name, levels = top20_drugs$Brnd_Name))  
ggplot(trend_data, aes(x = Year, y = Average_Spending, color = Brnd_Name)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  facet_wrap(~ Brnd_Name, scales = "free_y") + 
  labs(title = "Spending Trends for Top 20 High-Use Drugs (2018–2022)",
       subtitle = "A comparison of average spending per beneficiary over time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Average Spending per Beneficiary ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +  
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",  
    plot.title = element_text(size = 24, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 18, face = "italic", hjust = 0.5, color = "#6B6B6B"),  
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 15, color = "#666666", hjust = 0), 
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold", angle = 45, hjust = 1),  
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()  
  ) +
  scale_color_viridis_d()









trend_total_spending <- top20_drugs %>%
  select(Brnd_Name, Tot_Spndng_2018, Tot_Spndng_2019, 
         Tot_Spndng_2020, Tot_Spndng_2021, Tot_Spndng_2022) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("Tot_Spndng_"),
               names_to = "Year",
               names_prefix = "Tot_Spndng_",
               values_to = "Total_Spending") %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(Year),
         Brnd_Name = factor(Brnd_Name, levels = top20_drugs$Brnd_Name))


ggplot(trend_total_spending, aes(x = Year, y = Total_Spending, color = Brnd_Name)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1) +
  facet_wrap(~ Brnd_Name, scales = "free_y") +  
  labs(title = "Total Spending Trends for Top 20 High-Use Drugs (2018–2022)",
       subtitle = "Annual total spending for each top drug by 2022 spending",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Spending ($)",
       caption = "Data source: Medicare Part D Spending by Drug") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",  
    plot.title = element_text(size = 24, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 18, face = "italic", hjust = 0.5, color = "#6B6B6B"),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 15, color = "#666666", hjust = 0),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold", angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),
    strip.text = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"), 
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "#eaeaea", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  scale_color_viridis_d() 














Important



In the spending trend plots, each drug has its own y-axis range to better visualize its individual changes over time. This means that the y-axis scales are not uniform, and we should avoid making direct horizontal comparisons between drugs. Instead, focus on the trends within each drug.

title: Example Analysis
text: This analysis highlights the beneficiary cost burden and spending trends for the top 20 high-use drugs in Medicare Part D. In 2022, Strensiq, Myalept, and Vimizim emerged as the drugs with the highest average spending per beneficiary, reflecting their significant cost implications for individual patients. On the other hand, Acthar, Soliris, and Strensiq dominated total spending in 2022, underscoring their broader economic impact on the Medicare program.Spending trends from 2018 to 2022 reveal substantial variability among drugs, with some like Cinryze and Ravicti exhibiting relatively steady costs, while others like Haegarda and Acthar experienced significant fluctuations. These patterns suggest diverse factors influencing drug pricing, such as changes in demand, pricing strategies, or treatment availability.

title: Example Analysis
text:
Functions Used

dplyr
filter(): To subset the data, such as filtering for “Overall” manufacturers and excluding rows with missing values for spending.
arrange(): To sort the data by descending order of spending.
slice_head(): To select the top 20 drugs based on spending.
mutate(): To create new variables such as Year for trend analysis.
select(): To subset specific columns for trend analysis.

tidyr
pivot_longer(): To transform spending data from wide to long format for trend visualization.

ggplot2
geom_bar(): To create bar plots for spending per beneficiary and total spending.
geom_col(): As an alternative for bar charts with geom_bar().
geom_line(): To create line plots for spending trends over time.
geom_text(): To annotate bar plots with spending values.
facet_wrap(): To create faceted plots for trends, separating each drug into its own panel.
labs(): To add titles, subtitles, captions, and axis labels.
scale_color_viridis_d(): To assign distinctive colors for trend lines in faceted plots.
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma): To format y-axis values for better readability.
theme(): To customize the overall appearance of plots, such as adjusting text sizes, colors, and gridlines.

title: Yingqi Wang
text: Hello there! I’m Yingqi Wang, a second-year master’s student in Epidemiology with a passion for pharmacoepidemiology and data analysis. Currently my researches are mainly about utilizing real-world data to analyze the effectiveness and safety of medications, especially in neurodegenerative diseases.
